summary: This is an internal email from a prosecutor (likely from the Southern District of New York) to colleagues, discussing negotiations with Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team regarding an extension of discovery deadlines. The email details the defense's conditions for consenting to an extension and the prosecution's response, indicating ongoing pre-trial preparations in Maxwell's criminal case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case for which discovery deadlines are being negotiated. The defense is requesting conditions including providing her with a laptop to review discovery at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge overseeing the case to whom a formal letter regarding the extension and conditions must be sent.

connections.description: GM is acting as Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney, negotiating discovery deadlines and conditions on her behalf.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer in Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal case, making rulings on procedural matters like discovery deadlines.
Prosecutor R and defense attorney GM are negotiating procedural terms (discovery extension and conditions) in an adversarial legal context.

events.title: Negotiation of Discovery Extension
events.description: The prosecution and Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team negotiate conditions for extending discovery deadlines in her criminal case. The defense sets four conditions, to which the prosecution agrees to two.

events.title: Proposed Discovery Deadline
events.description: A proposed deadline by which the defense requests the prosecution provide: Maxwell with a laptop for discovery review at MDC, the names of Minor Victims, and all 3500 material.

locations: MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center) - Likely the facility where Ghislaine Maxwell was detained.
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team consented to a prosecution-requested discovery extension only under four specific conditions, indicating strategic negotiation over trial preparation.
The defense demanded the prosecution provide 'the names of the Minor Victims' by November 23, 2020, highlighting the central role of victim identification in the case.

The prosecution agreed to extend the motions schedule and provide Maxwell with a laptop at the MDC, but refused to agree to providing victim names and all 3500 material by the defense's demanded date.
The correspondence is an internal prosecution email discussing strategy for formal communication with the presiding judge, Judge Nathan.
The document references '3500 material,' which is likely a reference to Jencks Act or Rule 16 discovery material the prosecution must turn over to the defense.
